title: 艾伦·吉尔伯特联手史蒂芬·伊瑟利斯演绎德沃夏克《大提琴协奏曲》
short_description: 安东宁·德沃夏克的《b小调大提琴协奏曲》凭借其无穷的旋律变化以及浓厚的浪漫主义晚期色彩在所有大提琴协奏曲作品中脱颖而出。史蒂芬·伊瑟利斯曾被《电讯报》评价为“英国最伟大的大提琴家”，在本场音乐会中，他将联手艾伦·吉尔伯特为我们演绎这部美妙的协奏曲。除此之外，指挥吉尔伯特还指挥了波许斯拉夫·马蒂努表现二战之后人们身心得到解脱的《第四交响曲》。

interview.short_description: 2009年4月，艾伦·吉尔伯特指挥柏林爱乐乐团演出了几部捷克作曲家的作品。在这里，他与乐团的长笛演奏员艾曼纽·帕胡德进行了一次对话。

38

York, of course.

But the experience of

And there's so much
to react to.

48
00:01:47,910 --> 00:01:49,820
This program, of course,
is a very

49
00:01:49,820 --> 00:01:50,810
different kind of program.

50
00:01:50,810 --> 00:01:54,560
Wonderful, equally wonderful,
but all Czech music.

51
00:01:54,560 --> 00:01:59,040
And since I had such a nice
experience last time, I've

52
00:01:59,040 --> 00:02:01,320

00:02:01,320 --> 00:02:03,640
And I've looked forward
to this very much.

00:02:03,640 --> 00:02:07,230
And the rehearsals so far
have been a pleasure.

55
00:02:07,230 --> 00:02:11,180
I'm sure that many listeners,
world wide concert goers here

56
00:02:11,180 --> 00:02:14,090
in Berlin in the Philharmonic,

57
00:02:14,090 --> 00:02:17,230

58
00:02:17,230 --> 00:02:19,880

60
00:02:20,970 --> 00:02:23,500

61
00:02:23,500 --> 00:02:25,170

62
00:02:25,170 --> 00:02:29,210
Well, I like to do a huge

63
00:02:29,210 --> 00:02:32,120
And the Martinu symphony

64
00:02:32,120 --> 00:02:33,350
loved for a long time.

65
00:02:33,350 --> 00:02:37,970
And believe it or not, one of
the times I did the piece

00:02:37,970 --> 00:02:39,370

67
00:02:39,370 --> 00:02:41,200

00:02:41,200 --> 00:02:45,480

69

00:02:52,490 --> 00:02:56,080
That's, in a way, incidental.

72
00:02:56,080 --> 00:03:00,580
And once we had the Martinu
symphony idea basically set,

73
00:03:00,580 --> 00:03:04,640
then we decided to take the
Czech idea and run with it.

74
00:03:04,640 --> 00:03:06,940
And we came up with these
other pieces.

75
00:03:06,940 --> 00:03:09,600
Dvorak, of course, is probably
the best known

76
00:03:09,600 --> 00:03:10,900
of the Czech composers.

77
00:03:10,900 --> 00:03:14,270
And the Cello Concerto is
one of the most beloved.

78
00:03:14,270 --> 00:03:18,880
But the later tone poems, of
which the Noon Day Witch is

79
00:03:18,880 --> 00:03:21,850
one, are just amazing works.

80
00:03:21,850 --> 00:03:27,820
He really started to change
his style of composing.

81
00:03:27,820 --> 00:03:31,540
You could say that, he was
always a great composer, but

82
00:03:31,540 --> 00:03:33,600
he was really going into
a new direction.

83
00:03:33,600 --> 00:03:37,720
And you can almost see how
Janacek, who came after,

84
00:03:37,720 --> 00:03:39,940
picked up where Dvorak
left off.

85
00:03:39,940 --> 00:03:42,940
And these late tone poems are
on metaphysical, kind of

86
00:03:42,940 --> 00:03:44,890
supernatural themes.

87
00:03:44,890 --> 00:03:46,680
The stories are unusual.

88
00:03:46,680 --> 00:03:49,470
And actually, this particular
story is quite horrible.

89
00:03:49,470 --> 00:03:54,480
It's about the death of
a child, in fact.

90
00:03:54,480 --> 00:04:02,490
But he really started to
catapult, I think, Czech music

91
00:04:02,490 --> 00:04:05,590
into a completely
new territory.

92
00:04:05,590 --> 00:04:09,290
So you see, for instance in this
musical illustration of

93
00:04:09,290 --> 00:04:13,090
the terrible story of the Noon
Witch, you don't see only a

94
00:04:13,090 --> 00:04:16,040
purpose for writing some music
that would illustrate this,

95
00:04:16,040 --> 00:04:18,350
but really something structural
about the musical

96
00:04:18,350 --> 00:04:21,760
language that Dvorak used
in these tone poems.

97
00:04:21,760 --> 00:04:24,470
And that opened a new
way for Czech music.

98
00:04:24,470 --> 00:04:25,980
I think that's right.

99
00:04:25,980 --> 00:04:29,730
It's very operatic.

100
00:04:29,730 --> 00:04:34,130
It's very clear what the story
is about, and what the musical

00:04:34,130 --> 00:04:35,410

102
00:04:35,410 --> 00:04:38,990
You hear this little oboe, going

103
00:04:38,990 --> 00:04:39,950
child crying.

00:04:39,950 --> 00:04:42,560
And then you can tell when the
mother, who was sitting with

105

the child, becomes stern

106
00:04:45,060 --> 00:04:46,240
child, no, be quiet.

107
00:04:46,240 --> 00:04:47,230
Don't do that.

108
00:04:47,230 --> 00:04:49,300
And threatens the child.

109
00:04:49,300 --> 00:04:50,970
It's the old fashioned
way of parenting.

110
00:04:50,970 --> 00:04:52,190
I don't think that's the
way we're supposed

111

to do it these days.

112
00:04:53,310 --> 00:04:56,170
And threatens the child

113
00:04:56,170 --> 00:04:59,240
If you don't shut up, the Noon
Witch will come and get you.

114
00:04:59,240 --> 00:05:01,350
And you hear this scary,
ominous music.

115
00:05:01,350 --> 00:05:01,940
It's very clear.

116
00:05:01,940 --> 00:05:03,410
You can't miss it.

117
00:05:03,410 --> 00:05:07,560
And then things become calm and
normal, domestic again.

118
00:05:07,560 --> 00:05:09,940
And the baby starts
to cry again.

119
00:05:09,940 --> 00:05:11,780
And then you get this
threat again.

120
00:05:11,780 --> 00:05:14,320
And then, of course, what
happens is in this bizarre,

121
00:05:14,320 --> 00:05:17,670
romantic kind of supernatural
way, the threat of the Noon

122
00:05:17,670 --> 00:05:20,060
Day Witch actually becomes
a reality.

123
00:05:20,060 --> 00:05:23,610
And when the father, completely
unsuspecting, comes

124
00:05:23,610 --> 00:05:26,890
home at the end of the piece,
you can really tell that

125
00:05:26,890 --> 00:05:27,290
music, too.

126
00:05:27,290 --> 00:05:31,150
He's just ambling along, kind
of, everything is cool.

127
00:05:31,150 --> 00:05:32,020
Everything is normal.

128
00:05:32,020 --> 00:05:37,380
What he discovers is the work
that the Noon Day Witch,

129
00:05:37,380 --> 00:05:38,960
probably representing death.

130
00:05:38,960 --> 00:05:44,560
But it's not really clear where
reality is and where

131
00:05:44,560 --> 00:05:47,080
fantasy is.

132
00:05:47,080 --> 00:05:48,650
They become kind of
mixed together.

133
00:05:48,650 --> 00:05:52,240
In any case, it's
a pictorial--

134

it's a mini opera.

135

It's a mini opera, and

136

I'd like to hear some words from

4.

That's why we did this program,

these pieces having been

There might be something about

152

The Martinu Symphony no.

153

4 has been written, or
completed, in 1945, just at

the end of World War II,

155
00:06:46,150 --> 00:06:46,930
of World War II.

Well, it's clearly a reaction
to the war, this piece.

157
00:06:50,550 --> 00:06:56,390
It's also a kind of story in a
symphony, very differently

158
00:06:56,390 --> 00:06:59,370
realized from the Dvorak
tone poem.

159
00:06:59,370 --> 00:07:05,530
But you can hear in the first
movement, I believe, a kind of

160
00:07:05,530 --> 00:07:11,140
carefree optimism that is
shattered by the war-like

161
00:07:11,140 --> 00:07:13,530
second movement.

162
00:07:13,530 --> 00:07:16,610
And then the third movement

00:07:16,610 --> 00:07:20,160
reflective, spiritual realm.

00:07:20,160 --> 00:07:25,180
And you can feel the difficulty

165

the last movement that

There's a lot of celebrations,

Elliott Carter's 100th

But certainly, the Martinu is

212
00:09:42,150 --> 00:09:44,660
presence, the constant
presence of visiting

213
00:09:44,660 --> 00:09:45,140
orchestras.

214
00:09:45,140 --> 00:09:47,770
And of course, if an orchestra
such as Berlin can come,

215
00:09:47,770 --> 00:09:50,370
that's a privilege for
the city to hear.

216
00:09:50,370 --> 00:09:53,850
And also, it's nice for our
orchestra as well, to have

217
00:09:53,850 --> 00:09:58,150
that kind of musical activity
and that kind of focus on the

218
00:09:58,150 --> 00:09:59,110
hall where we play.

219
00:09:59,110 --> 00:10:01,920
And I know there were many
musicians from my orchestra

220
00:10:01,920 --> 00:10:04,480
who were able to come
to the concert.

221
00:10:04,480 --> 00:10:05,320
It was a great program.

222
00:10:05,320 --> 00:10:07,040
It was an unusual program.

223
00:10:07,040 --> 00:10:10,920
I remember particularly the
Webern Six Pieces, and the

224
00:10:10,920 --> 00:10:13,290
Stravinsky Symphony in
Three Movements.

225
00:10:13,290 --> 00:10:14,770
It was an unusual progression.

226
00:10:14,770 --> 00:10:16,140
But I think it worked
very well.

227
00:10:16,140 --> 00:10:18,300
And of course, it gave
the orchestra many

228
00:10:18,300 --> 00:10:20,120
ways to show itself.

229
00:10:20,120 --> 00:10:22,990
We now also have a residency in
Carnegie Hall, where we are

230
00:10:22,990 --> 00:10:25,190
returning every two
or three years.

231
00:10:25,190 --> 00:10:29,130
And that will allow us to see
each other, hopefully, if

232
00:10:29,130 --> 00:10:31,120
you're around, also at the same
time, very soon in the

233
00:10:31,120 --> 00:10:34,570
future, not only in Berlin
but also in New York.

234
00:10:34,570 --> 00:10:37,570
And I hope that, knowing that
you're going to be very busy

235
00:10:37,570 --> 00:10:39,740
in New York with the New York
Philharmonic from next

236
00:10:39,740 --> 00:10:43,485
September, that you will find
some time and visit us again.

237
00:10:43,485 --> 00:10:44,040
Thank you.

238
00:10:44,040 --> 00:10:44,920
It's been a pleasure.

239
00:10:44,920 --> 00:10:48,390
And one of the nice things about
building relationships

240
00:10:48,390 --> 00:10:51,250
with orchestras is that you
start to have friends in the

241
00:10:51,250 --> 00:10:51,900
various orchestras.

242
00:10:51,900 --> 00:10:55,740
And now I think even in addition
to you, I have quite

243
00:10:55,740 --> 00:10:57,870
a lot of people whom I
can consider friends.

244
00:10:57,870 --> 00:11:00,670
And it will be a pleasure to
meet you here or in New York

245
00:11:00,670 --> 00:11:02,140
or wherever.

246
00:11:02,140 --> 00:11:03,160
Thanks very much.

247
00:11:03,160 --> 00:11:06,130
And now back to the concert
for the second half of the

248
00:11:06,130 --> 00:11:09,180
broadcast of the Digital
Concert Hall.

249
00:11:09,180 --> 00:11:10,430
Thank you very much.

250
00:11:10,430 --> 00:11:11,160

metadata.title: 艾伦·吉尔伯特对话艾曼纽·帕胡德
metadata.description: 2009年4月，艾伦·吉尔伯特指挥柏林爱乐乐团演出了几部捷克作曲家的作品。在这里，他与乐团的长笛演奏员艾曼纽·帕胡德进行了一次对话。
